title: Sets and Set Operations
content:
Module 1, Lesson 8: Sets and Set Operations

The Hook

A set is a well-defined collection of distinct objects, called elements. Set theory, developed by Georg Cantor in the 19th century, provides the logical foundation for all of modern mathematics. The language of sets pervades every branch — from probability to topology to computer science.

The Concept

1. Set Notation

A set is written as {a, b, c, ...}. The empty set ∅ contains no elements. Membership is denoted x ∈ A (x is an element of A) or x ∉ A. Two sets are equal if they contain exactly the same elements.

2. Subsets and Power Sets

A is a subset of B (A ⊆ B) if every element of A is also in B. The power set P(A) contains all subsets of A. If |A| = n, then |P(A)| = 2ⁿ.

3. Set Operations

Union A ∪ B contains elements in A or B (or both). Intersection A ∩ B contains elements in both A and B. Complement Aᶜ contains elements not in A. Difference A \ B contains elements in A but not B. De Morgan's laws: (A ∪ B)ᶜ = Aᶜ ∩ Bᶜ and (A ∩ B)ᶜ = Aᶜ ∪ Bᶜ.

4. Venn Diagrams

Venn diagrams represent sets as overlapping circles within a universal set rectangle. They visualise intersections, unions, and complements intuitively and are widely used in probability and logic.

The Illustration

Sets are the language of mathematics. You learned set notation, subsets and power sets, the four fundamental operations (union, intersection, complement, difference), and De Morgan's laws. These concepts recur throughout all later modules.
